description:
[飲](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/飲) means *to drink*, and [品](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/品) is *item*, so [飲品](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/飲品) is basically *drink items*.

**Ordering**

[杯](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E6%9D%AF) is *cup* (or mug or glass) and is the [measure word](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Measure_word) for water (and other drinks), and [一](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E4%B8%80) means *one*, so to order a glass of water, ask for 一杯水 (yāt būi séui in Cantonese, yī bēi shuǐ in Mandarin), *one cup of water*.

{酒} refers to any alcoholic drink, but China has its own long history of liquor, including wine and beer. In fact, Chinese restaurants are often advertised as [酒家](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E9%85%92%E5%AE%B6) (*liquor house*).

**Characters**

Looking at the components of the character {酒}, [氵](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E6%B0%B5) is the radical for *water* (if you see this on a character, it probably has to do with something liquid), and [酉](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E9%85%89) resembles a wine vessel.

酒 is also Japanese (kanji) for sake.

Usually refers to non-alcholic cold drinks.

**Characters**

[冷](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E5%86%B7) is *cold*, and [飲](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E9%A3%B2) is *drink*, so [冷飲](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E5%86%B7%E9%A3%B2) is *cold drink*.

**Characters**

[熱](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E7%86%B1) is *hot*, and [飲](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E9%A3%B2) is *drink*, so [熱飲](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E7%86%B1%E9%A3%B2) is *hot drink*.
